comments: we moved a couple of years ago (locally) and spent a little over a year looking. we were moving to an area where boomers were selling off their “i never did a damn thing to this house but it was the shit in 1987" places for way more than they were worth. when they did update them the results were truly bizarre. so it took a while. what kept us from hating it was that we didn’t work with a realtor. so we didn’t have to schlep around to house after house every saturday or see places we already knew we wouldn’t like. we were pretty religious about scoping and analyzing ads online and about going to open houses. all the good places had open houses. we were only looking in a small area, not the whole city, so it was manageable and trends were easy to spot. anyway, one realtor we chatted up let us know of a place she was listing the day it came on the market. it wasn’t perfect, but it was pretty close. it cost $60k less than we were prepared(ish) to pay and had most of the big stuff already done. plus they had done some anal stuff a few years before like redoing the drainage and upgrading the windows that they were never going to get their money back on. hang in there! you will find something.

you’re getting into a chicken-egg argument here. they don’t actively court old, insecure white men. but they do have advertising to them because that’s who is watching the news. i mean, rachel maddow definitely doesn’t court them, and she has the highest rated show on msnbc. joy reid and ari melber definitely don’t, and i could go on naming more hosts who aren’t catering to old white men. the bigger issue here is that news reporting and discussion has always catered to the establishment because the establishment creates the news, but non-establishment (ie, non-old white men) audiences understandably can’t relate to all of that content and therefore just aren’t as interested in consuming as much of it. splashier docs and investigative reporting usually do better with those demos, but that shit is just too expensive and takes too much time to create on a regular basis. it’s an issue with the content, not the medium. even young and multicultural-geared websites like vice and buzzfeed news don’t reach as many of their intended audience as traditional news sites like nbcnews.com, despite them supposedly being the outlets covering the topics those audiences care about.

where is their merch? i can tell you where every team in dc plays their games, but i had to google the info for the soccerplex. there is no effort spent on making this team visible. perhaps it’s an oversight on the team’s management, or a deliberate slight, but either way, it’s dooming the team, just like it did for the washington freedom. i am really uninterested in whether this is deliberate or not, it’s not a murder trial, intent is irrelevant. if it’s mere incompetency, that’s just as bad in the long run. sure, there’s the good ole argument that women’s soccer games sell fewer tickets than men’s, but then the competent response is to ask “if women’s soccer is generating more revenue, and having a big sports moment right now, why aren’t ticket sales reflecting that?” to me, this would indicate that somewhere there’s a kink in the system (and i bet with a men’s sport, that would be the natural question), but to the people running the team and the sports world, it’s less an indication of a problem along the line and rather an indication that women are the problem and always will be, nothing to be done.

if you did have siri activated on your phone, you’d probably understand the limitations of it better. it doesn’t work unless you’re very close to it, it still regularly misunderstands what you’re saying even when you speak very clearly and directly to it, etc. it’s very obvious simply from using siri/alexa that the technology doesn’t yet exist to pick up on background noise from halfway across the room, pick out specific product keywords, and then translate that into functional advertising, which is what most people here are claiming it does. (it also would be very easy to tell if your phone was doing that, because it would require audio data to be constantly transmitted back to apple/whoever, which is something you can easily check up on.)

paper routes were the worst. i was 12-16. mine was 40 customers, spread out over 4 miles, daily morning delivery, year round in upstate ny. the papers weren’t in plastic bags to huck, no, i had to get off the bike, walk up and tuck it between the storm door and the front door of each customer, pulling my hand out and slamming the storm door before it slipped out the bottom. one local store would print an ad that was like  the size of today’s large cell phones, making the stack of papers lopsided and impossible to keep flat and organized in the bag. but yeah, 4 miles, in the snow, before school, every day.
the worst though was collecting. in the afternoon, i’d have to go to each customer’s house to collect $2.50/week ($1 sunday, 25cents per daily), and would have to pay the paper $2 for the papers. so $20/week if people didn’t rip me off. people wouldn’t be home, or wouldn’t have it on them. so i’d show up the next week, and they’d argue that they don’t owe that much, or why didn’t i come there last week, when i had. that’s the job where i realized people will indeed try to rip off a 12-year-old. best customer was the bar; they were always there when i collected, they always paid. also liked the old guys who only wanted the sunday paper; they’d just leave the dollar taped to their door. i had one customer, an old lady and her *mother*. must’ve been 80 and 100. they tipped me a dime a week, so they were good.

i have a very rare mast cell related disease. like clockwork, once a month a parent will pop up in one of the groupsand be convinced that vaccines are why their kid has it. no, that’s not how it works! i developed it at 3 weeks old which blows their theory out of the water plus the fact that my daughter also has a mast cell related disease. one of the groups is run by a fellow patient who happens to be a fantastic scientist and great at explaining the science. she has been threatened, has had people call her employer and harassed to know end. it does not help that kids with mastocytosis have a much higher rate of autism than the general population. i hear that and think that mast cell diseases just need to be investigated more for autism link, not vaccines. i get wanting to have a “reason” when a kid gets sick or dies but sometimes it is just shitty genes. we also have a very high prevalence of other rare diseases existing with autism such as gastroparesis, eds, pots, coeliac disease (the endoscopy verifiable kind), and some i have forgotten. the super fun part of this story is that parents of children with mast cell diseases are watched closely because we are legitimately at higher risk of having an anaphylactic episode or life threatening mast cell flare when getting vaccinated. the vast majority of parents still opt for the vaccines but make sure they have epi and monitor closely. my parents did not vaccinate me specialists advised against it because of herd immunity. ain’t that a kick in the head?

i realize this is a cat thread, but our dog has a permanent muscle tic from catching distemper as a puppy, before we adopted her. it’s apparently like measles for dogs; she had a bad case that went into her central nervous system. there’s no cure or real treatment for distemper, so she’s lucky to be alive. some muscle on her body is always moving, usually in her head. when she’s stressed it migrates to her jaw and we can hear it click; other times, her ears tic gently like a metronome. it doesn’t seem to bother her, but she was advertised as “special needs” by the rescue agency, because they weren’t sure whether it would get better, worse, or disappear entirely as she got older.

my pleasure. yes i see what you’re asking. the question is, if fosta / sesta will help trafficking victims somewhat, isn’t that worth some difficulties for those who consent? that might be close question, but in this case the overwhelming consensus is that the law doesn’t help trafficking victims at all. all the law does is allow cops to shut down websites that advertise any kind of prostitution. those websites did a few things. first, they made it possible for people for whom sex work was the best option to meet clients independently without having pimps. now that the sites are down, many sex workers will go back to pimps, who put them on the street where they are less safe. sex workers will lose freedoms working for pimps, like the freedom to leave the business or turn down work, so some of them will fall back into the category of coerced or trafficked because of fosta. so the law will probably increase trafficking.  second, those websites were great ways for cops to catch traffickers because the big established websites would cooperate with law enforcement if there was any reason to believe an advertisement was for trafficking victims. craigslist, backpage, and others worked with police to help them catch a lot of traffickers. now it is harder for the police to find the real criminals because they have to operate in a more hidden way. if what we really wanted to do was help trafficking victims, then the answer is to give sex workers the full protection of laws by removing all criminal penalties for the business. then no sex worker (or client) needs to fear going to the cops if there is evidence of sex trafficking. decriminalizing is the best way to fight trafficking, and most of the real trafficking victims support groups agree with that. so with fosta you have a law that hurts both trafficking victims and voluntary sex workers, because its proponents’ only real goal was to harass sex workers. the groups that pushed for fosta were the original anti-pornography groups of the 1980s along with religious conservatives. they are not victim advocates, but rather are morality-based groups.

i think part of the problem is the category of “trafficking” is pretty confused in the public debate. when people hear that word they imagine young girls kidnapped while walking home from school, bound and gagged, and shipped across the country. that is not what trafficking in the sex trade looks like. more often it’s runaways or people who might be doing sex work voluntarily anyway, but have fallen into abusive or exploitative labor conditions at the hands of pimps or boyfriends. so once you view trafficking crimes through the lens of a labor issue and not a kidnapping issue, you can see how fosta was not meant to help trafficking. consider that there is more human trafficking in manufacturing, agriculture, and domestic services than there is in sex work. if someone told you they were going to help trafficking victims in agriculture by banning advertisements for the purchase of vegetables, would you believe them? of course not. the way you help victims of coerced labor is by giving them the protection of labor laws and making sure they can go to the police without fear of repercussions.

for me, as someone who has worked in anti-trafficking programs for 11 years, this is a tough one. so many cases i have heard about and worked on involved victims who were advertised on backpage against their will. many of them minors whose traffickers were able to turn them out within hours using this website. i was actually very happy when backpage was shut down, but now idk how i feel because i really see where these women are coming from and also see that this perspective wasn’t something this law took into account (which is true with a lot of new legislation).

i worked in the juvenile justice system in a major american city and we would sometimes be alerted by clients if they had friends (or they themselves) were being trafficked and were utilizing backpage. i will never forget the visceral feeling of horror and disgust i experienced when i saw one of my 13-year-old female clients being advertised on backpage. with that experience in mind, my initial reaction to this article was that shutting down backpage is a good thing and anyone who thinks something to the contrary is an idiot.

licensing takes a lot of time and effort and is rather bound up in legal paperwork/terminology. that’s why families of famous people either sell the rights to these companies outright or hire them to do the negotiating in their place. i think in this case, the advertising company just did a bad job in parsing the national attitude and what people’s reaction would be. their pitch to the licensing company was probably really sincere.

i figured that licensing was a big enough of a to-do that mlk’s family would have professionals helping them manage it, i’m just surprised that they’d cede so much control that none of them have final approval on something like this. i don’t think dodge deserves all of the blame here: what they did was tone deaf and clumsy, but i expect corporate advertisers to be tone deaf and clumsy. what i don’t expect is for a group as active at managing their ip as the mlk estate has been to make a deal with a fucking car company to cut a super bowl ad using one of mlk’s speeches without insisting that they see and approve the ad before it’s finalized. this just seems like sloppy management.

yeah the weber thing is no surprise. i remember picking up one of those abercrombie & fitch catalogues from the 90s and it was mostly very young looking male models in various stages of nudity. some of the shots were surprisingly porn-y for ads designed to sell cheap clothing to teenagers, and the overall effect was some dirty old man’s fantasy of what kids do on the weekends.

i think perhaps the fashion industry is just reacting to the wave of accusations and the loud call for corporations/people in power to hold accusers accountable. these stories are reaching a wider audience right now and it could financially hurt any business seen as protecting abusers. i didn’t know about testino/weber but richardson has been a known predator for years with no repercussions. a friend of mine was fired off of his shoot for a major clothing brand ad campaign after talking back to him when she observed inappropriate behavior with a very underage model. she was reprimanded by her modeling agency for getting fired.

i think having better representation of all women’s body types in advertising/online shopping websites could be potentially be beneficial to both the buyer and consumer. i know i would be more likely to buy  clothing items if i saw body type like my own when clicking through the images. i’m a straight-sized “pear” and i often don’t know what i’ll look like in a dress until i try it on because usually models are “bananas” or “hourglasses”.

i don’t have a problem with this model’s body, because i do not want anyone to have a problem with mine. my issue is that this is an ad for eye wear. why does the model have to be thin? i’m pretty fat and i’ve worn glasses my whole life...but i’ve never seen a fat eye wear model. diversity is the key here. show me fat, thin, muscular, disabled, latinx, black, asian, native models. don’t vilify one model to lift another.
